Reviews.Title: Really good laptop
Reviews.Author: nikki
Reviews.Content: I was looking for a computer that compared in size and style of the MacBook 13 inch. This did everything I expected. When searching for a new computer I wanted a small portable computer but didn't want to sacrifice hard drive or ram space. I love this, this 11.6 is very easy to view and easy to carry around. The only complaints I have are the battery life which is really not a big deal because the charger is fairly small and easy to carry around, and also there is no cd/dvd drive which does not bother me either because most things can be transferred to and from the computer through a usb jump drive.Pros: backlit keyboard, great ram and hard drive size, portableCons: short battery life, no cd/dvd drive

Reviews.Title: Nice sub-$500 notebook with touchscreen
Reviews.Author: Ben D.
Reviews.Content: Pros-Nice build quality (for sub $500)Great looking screenResponsive touchBacklit keyboardProcessor turbo to 1.4ghz (after some power settings tweaks)Advanced bios can be enabled (search the web)I paid four twenty-nine for my a6-1450 with 6GB just a few days agoRuns Ubuntu with the correct graphics driversCons-Windows 8 blows! Seriously!Trackpad can be finickyWeak cameraHard drive is the bottleneckOverall a pretty decent notebook for the money.

Reviews.Title: Good Components and Construction
Reviews.Author: J. Stateham
Reviews.Content: Pros:-Zero chassis flex-Keyboard is solid (no flex)-IPS panel touchscreen-Decent CPU-4GB of Ram-Backlit keyboardCons:-Keyboard keys are a little small due to chiclet design on an 11.6" laptop-Battery life is mediocre- my last Acer in this price category had an 8 hour battery life-Mouse pad requires a strong tap to register a "click"-Screen is not as bright as it could be-No extended battery or dock available yetOther:-HDD is large but slow (like most laptops)- I switched it out for a 180GB SSD-Windows 8 is frustrating and unintuitive-Need dongles/adapters for VGA/DVI/HDMI outOverall I like this little laptop. My last Acer (Acer One) beat the pants off of it in battery life, but I knew that when I bought it. Windows 8 hasn't won me over yet either and the touchscreen is nice, but I rarely find myself wanting or needing to utilize it. Really want the extended battery and dock that was promised to be released, but it doesn't look like Acer is in any hurry. Overall this little laptop is great for what I use it for- a content viewer. For content creation I use a triple screen desktop setup with Windows 7. Adding ReviverSoft's Start Menu Reviver definitely helps adjust to Windows 8 and makes it more usable, but I'm still partial to 7. Great little portable though- after the One and the V5 I don't think I could ever go back to a 15"+ laptop (previous to the Acer One I had an Alienware m7700 17" DTR). The SSD and a $5 HDMI out dongle were the only additions I made.Pretty happy with this laptop and the build quality and chassis rigidity is spectacular- much better than the Acer One. The keyboard is better as well- but the keys are a bit smaller, so it takes some getting used to. Great price here on Amazon as the BestBuy model doesn't have the backlit keyboard.I definitely recommended!

Reviews.Title: Perfectly for my needs.
Reviews.Author: Juan Varela
Reviews.Content: The laptop its great it works perfectly and the touchscreen its a very good extra.I recommend for that who need a small but functional laptop.

Reviews.Title: What a great surprise. Please read for some necessary adjustments.
Reviews.Author: F-Rod
Reviews.Content: Been looking for a laptop to replace my trusty HP Elitebook 2530p, a 13.3" Win7 machine. Although I love my 2530p, it's older, doesn't have USB3.0 or HDMI. When I saw this deal, it was time to strike. Bought this on a one-day Amazon deal, $378/shipped.It was the laundry list of goodies that piqued my interest; 11.6" IPS touch display, HDMI (via mini DisplayPort to HDMI adapter), USB3.0, backlit keyboard, quad-core with dedicated GPU and Windows 8. 500GB 5400RPM HDD and 4GB RAM were par for this level of laptop. The other features seems pretty high end.The screen is nice. It's bright. It's got excellent contrast levels and yes, even though it's 1366x768, the 11.6" screen is very forgiving. That resolution at this size looks perfectly fine. This will do till 1920x1080 becomes available in an 11.6" or 13.3" screen, which seems to be very expensive at this time. But no worries, the screen is GREAT. Touch works well. I'm not a huge fan of Windows 8 Metro, it's OK...but won't replace desktop mode anytime soon.USB3.0 on this system is fast. I created an Acer Recovery USB thumb-drive on two separate USB sticks. You'll need at least a 16GB drive for this. On USB2.0, it seems to take forever. With USB3.0, it was allot quicker. If you want to connect this to an HDTV, you will need a mini DisplayPort to HDMI adapter, found one on eBay for $5/shipped. Works perfect. Love the backlit keyboard. Been wanting one for a while and finally got one. Works great. Will shut off by itself if you don't use it. You also have the option to disable it.OK, the APU...this is AMD's terminology for a single die that contains both the CPU and a dedicated GPU. An Accelerated Processing Unit. The CPU and GPU handled most everything I threw at it. Let's be realistic, you're not going to be running Crysis3 on this. But, I was able to load up Sine Mora and GRID. Both ran decently at normal or low settings. VERY SUPRISED by this. I did have one issue with VLC media player, when I went to run 1080p video, it would occasionally drop a frame or two. As an avid video watcher, I could easily tell. After some investigating, I figured it out, VLC media player does not use the GPU for decoding by default. 720p videos had no problems, it was the larger 1080p videos that taxed the CPU, at times spiking it to about 100%. Once I enabled GPU decoding, the video stutter/dropped frames problem went away. I could not get this to drop a frame. After enabling this CPU load was about 2/3 lower. By the way, this laptop is QUIET. Even with the fan running, you can hardly hear it.Another thing, as you may or may not know, the power settings in Windows will dramatically adjust the CPU power on this system. So, in Power Saver mode, you can actually see the CPU go down to about .580GHz or 580MHz...yes, the battery will last longer, slightly over three hours. I've seen the power meter say 4.5 hours. At High Performance mode, the CPU idles at 1.0GHz and will boost to 1.4GHz.The keyboard feels light and snappy. Smooth keys with good feedback. The mouse is fine. I'm not a huge fan. There is some play and it sounds cheap.Windows 8, well, I'm not going to bother going into this. I have an opinion that I will keep to myself. BUT, to make Windows 8 usable in any form or fashion, you must download Windows 8 Classic Shell. It brings back the Start button. Without this, how would I have known applications were even on this system? I just don't get it. But I am so glad Classic Shell is installed. It makes this laptop so much more functional. Metro is cute but, productivity wise, it is useless to me. I already have an iPad3. I have absolutely no use for Metro. With Windows8 Classic Shell...it's a PC again! Yay! Also, Windows 8 Task Manager is AWESOME. The best Task Manager EVER! If you want to nerd out, dive in and enjoy. Stats/graphs on everything. Good stuff.Anyways...that's pretty much it. Oh, one other thing...4GB of RAM is OK. It's not great, but it's not bad. I never found myself hitting the 4GB ceiling, so I don't think it will be a problem. The 500GB drive is a 5400RPM, which is too bad. 5400RPM is so 1994. It works fine. I'm just used to an SSD in my gaming rig and work and home laptops. I think an SSD would rock in this thing. BUT, I would lose capacity. At this point, I prefer capacity over speed. Once Black Friday comes around, I will be tempted to purchase a 256GB SSD for this. Be warned, if you plan on swapping out the drive, you will need a 7mm drive. I tried slapping in an SSD and could not fit it in. There is a flat cable that goes over the HDD, if the new drive is larger, the cable will not make it to the connector on the mobo.I was very close to returning it due to the rendering issue which was not the fault of the PC but rather the application. Now that it's been resolved, via the application, this laptop is a keeper. And no, it's not an Macbook Air, but for a third of the price, it's such a great bargain. I would totally recommend it.UPDATE---08/10/2013Still loving this little laptop. One thing I wanted to mention, my laptop shipped with BIOS firmware 2.03...I checked Acer's Support site and found the latest update to be 2.08. Unfortunately, Acer does not specify what the fix is when you update the BIOS. No mention at all. Bad on Acer. In any case, I tried to update to 2.08 and could not, had to be on 2.06 first. So, I gave that a shot. No luck...upgraded to 2.05, then 2.08. Worked fine. I'm not sure what this will gain you. Just wanted to let you know. UPDATE BIOS AT YOUR OWN RISK. If you lose power in the middle of updating it, you will essentially brick it and have to send it back, with all the data, to Acer and they will not get your data back.It goes without saying, I removed any and all crapware; hi there Norton. There's not much, just a couple of things. Also, ran a hard drive test. On battery setting "Performance" I was seeing a Max read speed of 122MB/s. For a little crappy 5400RPM HDD, that's pretty good.UPDATE---03/06/2014Still have this laptop. It's my main go-to laptop around the house. No issues with laptop at the present time. I replaced the HDD with a Samsung Evo 240GB SSD. The difference is night and day. The machine is very fast. Boot time is easily 8-10 seconds, if that. When using Chrome, if you are in Battery Saving mode, when you scroll, you can see a little bit of stutter depending on the complexity of the website. If you go into High Performance mode, this goes away. It's a dual edge sword because battery life goes way down in High Performance mode. So there is a trade off. The external battery is available, but is $100 from Acer. Part number is NP.BTP11.00G.The IPS display is beautiful. The backlit keyboard is a must. I still don't like the mouse pad because of the level of play. You can tell there is a bit of space. I usually tap it lightly and you can hear it kinda click. I'm tempted to put a thin piece of foam between the mouse surface piece and it's backing. That would resolve the issue.In any case, it's the best small/thin laptop I've owned. How can you beat this for what I paid? I can't wait to see the follow up.BTW, USB 3.0 and the mini display port are awesome. I use a cheap Mini Display port to HDMI adapter to run the video to my A/V system. Works great. I'm in HTPC heaven with that. And also, you can actually do some light gaming on this thing. Don't expect much, but it's impressive.

Reviews.Title: False Specifictations, does not have everything listed! What a joke.
Reviews.Author: Tyler Goff "Media Junkie"
Reviews.Content: This is a 4-star laptop for the price, but it's downgraded because of completely incorrect specifications!! Their website states this exact model has an HDMI and Ethernet port... but it has neither!!! You'd like to think this is an honest mistake, but I highly doubt it. The laptop itself looks really nice, and it's okay at responding to basic web browsing and watching movies. It's very thin and light, the battery could be better, but it's only 3 cell so it does okay. I would highly recommend putting in a Solid State Drive, it's fairly simple and only takes about 15 minutes. In conclusion: nice travel-friendly laptop, but SHAME ON ACER FOR FALSE ADVERTISING.Source:[...]- Only 2 USB ports, not 3- NO HDMI Port- NO Ethernet Port

Reviews.Title: Wonderful compact touchscreen
Reviews.Author: Amazon Customer "Doc Guy"
Reviews.Content: I had this computer for a little over a month, and I really liked it. It was a perfect size for carrying around, and I loved the touch screen. I bought mine from Staples and purchased a Square Trade warranty with accidental damage protection. (Incidentally, after I had it for a month a family member knocked a glass of water on it, and it was ruined.)PROS:The touchpad was very nice, and the keys were responsive.The laptop was the lightest computer I've ever had, and it was exceptionally portable.It came with a VGA adapter. I purchased an HDMI adapter from a third-party, and that worked great as well.CONS:The processor is not designed for heavy lifting. If you need to run a processor-intensive program (like image editing, software compiling, etc.) then you should look for a machine with an Intel Core i5 or Core i7 processor. If you are running Win 8 apps, or using basic tools like word processing and the like, you probably won't notice a huge difference, but when you start trying to do any heavy lifting at the processor level, you'll feel like you are crawling along.The battery life is right around 3 hours, in my experience. I wished it were a bit longer, but I knew about the lower battery life going into the purchase, so I wasn't disappointed, per se, but the 3 hour span was a bit more inconvenient than I expected.Not waterproof (just kidding). Ok, the true thing to note here is that the battery is totally enclosed in the case. There is no way to remove the battery. When my SIL spilled water on the computer (while it was running), the keyboard immediately stopped working, and my only option was to press-and-hold the power button to shut the device down. I wanted to remove the battery right away and let the device dry, but I didn't have the correct-size of screw driver to get out the screws (and taking off the back cover voids your warranty, at least with some laptop manufacturers). In any case, I think the computer might have been saved from permanent damage if I could have removed the battery, but that was not an option for me. (Luckily I had the Square Trade Warranty, so me and my SIL are still friends. :)When I had to replace this computer, I decided that I wanted a computer with a little more oomph in the processor and a longer battery life, so I didn't re-purchase this little beauty, though I did really like it and would buy it again if I needed something that didn't have to be a workhorse.

Reviews.Title: SLOW
Reviews.Author: jack
Reviews.Content: This was just a slow computer. The typing for my schoolwork was slow, the characters came up 10 seconds after I typed them and most didn't show up at all. Also, the processor is slow. IE takes forever to load, it will take almost 30 seconds for any page to load, and it is just not good.

Reviews.Title: Perfect little travel computer
Reviews.Author: Kathleen Taylor
Reviews.Content: I needed a small, light, new computer that would fit in my carry-on for travel. This Acer fits the bill perfectly. The transition to Windows 8 was fairly painless (if you use a touch screen phone, it's very much the same, plus there is an old-style desktop to work from if it all gets too confusing). In case it's not clear, the MS Office Suite that comes with the computer is a trial version, not a fully functional (or paid-for) Office.

Reviews.Title: Decent small notebook, slightly under powered
Reviews.Author: John E. Scott
Reviews.Content: If your not into major multi tasking this little notebook should satisfy most. I have been pleasantly surprised by Acer in the V5 122p and although I think the AMD APU A6 1450 is a bit under performing on the CPU portion. The GPU makes up for some of that handling a lot of the graphic work. The notebook runs cool and battery life is OK considering battery size. About my only complaint has nothing to do with the notebook and everything to do with Windows 8 and Acer's "value added" software and tools. Once I removed a lot of Acer's tools and value added software. My Acer V5 performed much better. Why these PC makers continue to degrade their PC's with redundant and unwanted stuff is a wonder to me? As for Windows 8 I don't like it and never will. I do well with it because I stay within the classic desktop and rarely go into the "modern" desktop environment. I doubt Windows 8.1 will solve many of my own complaints. Don't get me wrong, Windows 8 is stable, fast and probably more battery conserving then Windows 7. I just don't care to juggle between two different user interfaces on a notebook. Which brings me to my biggest issue. Having to clean fingerprints all the time from the screen! Touch screens biggest Achilles heal is having to clean them. I refrain from inputting with the touch screen on my Acer because it shows all the fingerprints.I think Acer has a winner on its hands with this notebook, its compact, has OK performance for most users and looks and feels better then what it is.

Reviews.Title: A touchscreen is a must for Windows 8...
Reviews.Author: Amy Phipps
Reviews.Content: I've been using this laptop for a little over a month, and overall, I really like it. It's not the fastest, most powerful thing out there, nor does it have all the bells and whistles, but as a good, basic touchscreen laptop, this gets the job done at a reasonable price.Pros:Screen: If you're wondering why you even need a touchscreen, then I'd guess you've never had the joy (insert sarcasm here) of experiencing Windows 8. Windows 8 was designed with tablets and touchscreens in mind, and thus is a nightmare to maneuver through with just a track pad or a mouse. If you're running Windows 8, you want a touchscreen. This is a very good touchscreen, nice and responsive, with great resolution and good colors to boot.Touchpad: The touchpad on this laptop is fantastic! It's very responsive when you touch it, but not so sensitive that it engages when you're only trying to type. You can right click and left click just like with a mouse, and you can use two fingers to zoom in or out. This is definitely one of my favorite things about this laptop.Keyboard: I spend a lot of time typing, so the quality of the keyboard is of huge importance to me. This keyboard has a great feel to it, and despite the compact nature of the laptop itself, doesn't feel too cramped or small. I love that it's backlit, and I was super happy to find that it has dedicated Pg Up and Pg Down buttons... my other laptops don't and it's such a huge pain.Price: At just a little over $400, this is definitely one of the lower-priced touchscreen laptops out there. Yet it has a very high-quality feel and sturdy construction... nothing about it is "cheap" except the price.Cons:Speed: This laptop was unbearably slow when I first got it. Now that we've removed a lot of the sample software and other pre-installed junk, it's better, but still definitely a bit sluggish. Opening anything takes a few seconds longer than I'm used to, and starting up from a total shut-down takes FOREVER. Everything seems to run well enough once opened, so it's not a huge problem, but if you're an impatient person like I am, you may find this a bit annoying.Battery: The battery life of this laptop is just so-so. It gets me about 2.5 hours and that's it.  Amazon's product description states that you can add on an external second battery, but Acer doesn't currently sell them in the US. I run on wall power most of the time so I don't really mind, but if you need extended battery performance, this may not be the laptop for you.CD/DVD Drive: It has none. I know many people don't have a need for them nowadays, but I miss it.Bottom line? This is a good laptop for the cost. If you're looking for a lower-priced, entry-level laptop, I recommend.

Reviews.Title: Acer V-5
Reviews.Author: J. Jensen
Reviews.Content: This little computer is a real gem.  Especially like the backlit keyboard.  Touchscreen is real reason for buying and it works very well.Just be better with smaller fingers.  Only thing is the processor speed appears to be needing a boost.  At 1.0 G things are slowto me and I know next to nothing about computer operations, just takes to long to load apps in my opinion.

Reviews.Title: I love it!
Reviews.Author: Jonathan
Reviews.Content: Exactly what I expected from this laptop. I needed it for school and so far it has been working wonders. One thing I do advise however is to make sure to install all the updates when you boot it up for the first time. It will take several hours but it needs to be done. Other than that it took me a while to get used to Windows 8 but it works seamlesslessy

Reviews.Title: A non-techie review
Reviews.Author: Misfit
Reviews.Content: I see several other reviewers have mentioned the technical aspects of this laptop, but things like GBs and RAMs and whatnot go right over my head. I just want something that starts up and loads programs quickly without getting buggy and unstable. This is my first experience with Windows 8, and quite a learning curve, although after downloading an app with hints, I'm soldering on a bit better. Still, I prefer Windows 7, and please note that any comments I make about the operating system and/or the Microsoft programs are directed towards them and not the manufacturer. I leave it up to the individual to decide if a laptop with Windows 8 is a good fit for them or not - although I suspect eventually we'll all have to learn it, like we had to (learn) with all those other operating systems of fading memory.Out of the package, set up was a real breeze. Plug it in (it charged to full capacity fairly quickly), turn on the power button, set up your passwords and what-not. Connecting to WIFI was a snap, but after that you have to let things take their course for all the updates - both Windows and most of the installed programs/tiles. I recommend only updating one app at a time, things really bogged down while all that  downloading was going on. I like the backlit keyboard a lot, I'd find that very handy in a darker setting. I haven't tested the battery to the very end of life before it needs charging, but I've gone several hours before getting a low life warning.This does come with an email program, but I'm unable to use it. It says it's not compatible with POP servers and I've just switched everything over to a new email that is POP only, and I'm not going through that again. I did try the free trial of MS Office, but I can't see myself using it on this unit. I'm from the old school of typing, where you went to class and learned to type at the speed of light, and the keyboard on this laptop doesn't seem to like that kind of typing (same as the Fire, it's all hunt and peck). I find myself slowing down and hitting the keys hard to get my keystrokes to stick. If I wanted to type anything more than a sentence or two in a comment box, I'm still going to turn on the desk top and use Word there. Same for Excel, the program worked fine on the laptop, but I can't fathom trying to work with an accounting based spreadsheet without a ten-key. *shudders*I was able to get my music transferred fairly easily, and have tried it in Amazon's Cloud Player app as well as the Xbox program that comes with the laptop. I ended up liking the installed music program a lot when I figured out I could set it on a sidebar and I get images of the artist playing, plus suggestions for other titles to listen to. The speakers sound a bit tinny, but much improved after I plug into it with some earbuds/headphone.I'm not a huge gamer, but I have downloaded some solitaire programs and a Mahjong app from Microsoft - the latter being a bit on the *twee* side for my tastes, I much prefer the 247 Mahjong app on my Fire. I like the MS solitaire program a lot, and the graphics are great on the laptop, but the ads that come with the free app are annoying as you-know-what, plus it frosts me that I'm asked to sign into a Microsoft account to play a game of solitaire (I just click don't sign in and then play).Back to the programs/tiles, I haven't tried them all (don't Skype, Twitter, etc.). You can click onto IE explorer from the desk top, but I really dislike the way that app works. If you like the old-fashioned IE experience, go to the desk top (there's a tile to click to take you there), and you'll find the blue "e" button at the bottom task bar. I've also downloaded Chrome and have been using that as well. YMMV. I did find a very helpful tutorial for Windows 8, and I will post a link to it in the comment field.I haven't shopped laptops and prices much, but this appears to be an excellent value in its price range, and one I'd recommend if Windows 8 is a good fit - those not open to change and learning new things might not find this the best fit, but I'm having a good time getting to learn a thing or two. Plus kitty likes to be a lap kitty and she hates it when I'm at the desk top for too long, like I am now.Final note:  I did have trouble on a couple of occasions getting this laptop to power on, just got the Acer screen and then nothing, but I haven't had this problem again, so fingers crossed it was just something I did.

Reviews.Title: Add $300 to the price to buy a new hard drive and switch back to windows 7
Reviews.Author: Nicholas Sowden "Nick"
Reviews.Content: Oh my gosh, I am so frustrated with this computer! Who makes a product that doesn't even work 2 weeks? Microsoft 8 started moving slow, then slower. When I changed something in microsoft office or word it takes about 3 seconds to "process". Then it has progress that the windows 8 "auto repair" and "quick repair" have to repair my microsoft office everytime I open it. Now they're completely gone.I just paid $300 to get a new hard drive and have Windows 7 installed. Made my $500 laptop a $800 one. :(Buy something with windows 7.

Reviews.Title: like description, therefore, a little slow
Reviews.Author: moi
Reviews.Content: Well, is exactly like description. Light weight, nice, but a little slow. if you are a pacient person, is great for you!

Reviews.Title: Excellent performer.
Reviews.Author: Steven McGrogan
Reviews.Content: It has performed solidly and as expected once I cleared the bloat ware that came installed. Touch screen is quick and responsive, which is really the reason to buy this machine.

Reviews.Title: Too slow
Reviews.Author: TC
Reviews.Content: This computer is very light and has a good battery life but I won't recommend it.Pros: Great value, light, battery life, touchscreenCons: Windows 8, Amd a6 processor is agonizingly slow, takes too long to load pagesOverall, it is a bad computer and I totally regret buying it.

Reviews.Author: Jian Jiao
Reviews.Content: it's slow...and uncomfortable, amd and win8 are terrible...wish they could improve it in the future, choose something other than acer v5 ...i suggest

Reviews.Title: It's a nice computer.....I returned it.
Reviews.Author: RONALD P NEWBERG
Reviews.Content: It did not match the mfgr's specs.....there was no HDMI AND ONLY 1 usb3 port.It is pretty...  Upgrading to Windows 8.1 was a nightmare.

Reviews.Title: Acer Aspire V5 - Quite a great little laptop
Reviews.Author: Cycleguy
Reviews.Content: I bought my Acer Aspire V5 122 with the AMD 1450 processor and 6GB DDR3 memory at a local retail store.  I am writing this review only because of a couple of odd reviews criticizing these model laptops.One reviewer mentioned "This will not ruin AutoCad."  No. It will not. This is a sub $500 laptop. It sits on the shelf next to $1,400 to $1,700 laptops that probably will run AutoCad.  If THAT is the capability you need to have, open your wallet up further and get one designed for that purpose. This Acer Aspire will happily run PhotoShop, Illustrator, Word, Excel, Acrobat and 98% of the software 98% of the people need to run.  I even use PowerDirector 10 video editor on mine.  It is slower than when I run the same video editor on my desktop PC with the i7 CPU and a killer video card but the video card cost more than this entire little computer!I have a 6 year old Dell XPS M1210 laptop.  It was one of the fastest laptop PCs available at the time I bought it.  This Acer is very similar to it in speed.  Yes, there are MUCH faster and more capable laptops available today, but you need to start ADDING $200, $400, $600 or ever $1000 to get one of these faster ones.The touchscreen on this one is beautiful.  The battery lasts around 3.5 hours.  I've seen better battery lifes and faster laptops, but not everything at this low of a price.. The screen is exceedingly clear and bright.  Knowing this inexpensive little PC will run those two programs is probably more significant to 98% of consumers that having them be concerned that it will not run a CAD/CAM program.The build differences are quite noticeable. The Dell was built like a tank in comparison.  it had access doors on back for each item: battery, hard drive, memory stick, wi-fi and bluetooth cards. These new laptops are ultra light weight.  This Acer is trim, thin and elegant, built more like an Apple "air" laptop than the old Dell was.

Reviews.Title: Too much pre-loaded junk
Reviews.Author: baja
Reviews.Content: Acer needs to dump all the bloat apps and pre-loaded programs that slow this nice little computer to a crawl. Clear out this mess and it will run faster and much, much better.

Reviews.Title: Most Amazing PC!
Reviews.Author: BlueHeart84
Reviews.Content: I absolutely adore this laptop!!! for the extra money getting more RAM and a faster processor was worth it! The touchscreen is amazing and the screen resolution just whooooo!!! :) it's so light weight and fits into my camel pak so I can take it every where I go and pairing it with my bluetooth devices is not hard at all :)

Reviews.Title: overall good.
Reviews.Author: Xinyi Xiong
Reviews.Content: well the reason I bought this laptop is because my laptop is too large(15'6) and too heavy to bring to school everyday and I found myself really need a laptop in school work. I'm looking for a cheap and light one. I think this one satisfied my requirements. It's good-looking and it's light. But I won't say it has a good CPU. Sometimes it just run really slow... Like one time I starting up the laptop and it started to update some software i installed, it took a WHOLE CLASS to finish updating. I'm just so upset about that.

Reviews.Title: acer aspire touchscreen laptop
Reviews.Author: glee l hansen
Reviews.Content: I likd that it is very compact and light. easy to take with you anywhere. love the touch screen feature also.

Reviews.Title: Dissappointed.
Reviews.Author: lowanda
Reviews.Content: Looks good that's all I say positive. Third time using, constantly froze. Bad investment. Don't know if it's the product or the person whom I purchased it form. If I can't find a solution I will return.

Reviews.Title: Exactly what I needed!
Reviews.Author: alphavictor
Reviews.Content: My wife needed a small, compact, lightweight device to do light work!This device fit her requirement, her handbag, and my wallet perfectly!Windows 8 has a pretty steep learning curve since my wife's current laptop ran Windows XP!!One problem I'm having is that the prongs of the wall charger adapter do not stay completely inside the wall socket, but pop out about 5 mm due to the weight of the adapter itself. Not sure if this is a problem with just all the sockets in my house or this adapter! My other adapters (I have a Samsung Galaxy S2, a B&N; Nook, and a Nexus 7 FHD) stay in the sockets with no problem.One more gripe, and this one with Win8 is that closing an app is not as simple as clicking the "X" at the top right corner! You need more clicks and swipes now!

Reviews.Title: Nice touch computer for $$$, but Windows 8 is HORRIBLE
Reviews.Author: Laura
Reviews.Content: I really like this computer, the touch screen is very responsive, love the backlit keyboard really sharp, nice design, lightweight with strong graphics and performance; however, i dislike the hidden power button and the large amount of bloatware that I'm in the process of removing ... This is my first experience with Windows 8 and thankfully this computer is a laptop touch screen ... otherwise I would have to return simply due to the Windows 8 experience ... as a sidenote ... what the *&(*^%*&%*& was MICROSOFT THINKING ... PLEASE stay CLEAR OF WINDOWS 8 IF YOU are REPLACING Any DESKTOP (touchscreen or not) or a laptop without a touch screen unless you just feel like forcing yourself to learn something COMPLETELY new... WINDOWS 8 is a guessing game... you will get lost in a program and shout how do I get out of this? Buttons will be hidden and you will never know they exist... GO TO YOUTUBE AND LOOK UP videos of people using 8 for the first time ... windows 8 is an awkward mishmash that pulls the user in two directions with the new touch Metro, users will dislike having to navigate Metro to find settings and apps they intuitively locate in Windows 7

Reviews.Title: acer is the best
Reviews.Author: Terri Awoko
Reviews.Content: I was very impressed with this computer I didn't know how fast that it would go you can play grand theft auto 5 on low settings a bit sluggish though but I was impressed you can play Grand Theft Auto 4 on medium settings and I love minecraft you can play Minecraft on high settings but I don't know about the a4 chip very fast and focus computer can play good games and if you have an xbox you have a hell of a time with this computer because it's fun to connect it with a xbox and I really like Windows 8 and it's touch  even the more merrier I would highly recommend computer for gamers for everyday use for everything you can think ofin my opinion the processor speed is better than the ivy  bridge processors but not the really high one  I got mine craft to go at 68 frames per second on high amazing I love it and I am a GIRLLL

Reviews.Title: Trash!
Reviews.Author: lora murphy
Reviews.Content: Horrible.  Just horrible. This little laptop looks cute.  Then you use it.  It freezes all the time.  ALL THE TIME.  As in every single time I use it.  It is so frustrating.  I have not added any software or anything to it that would slow it down. It is a piece of junk made to break..  I will never buy Acer again.  What a ripoff!

Reviews.Title: Great Laptop but no HdMI
Reviews.Author: Larry Mondorf
Reviews.Content: Love this laptop but only gave it 4 stars because it does not have HDMI as it states in product description section. Even Acer.com says it has a HDMI port but actually none of the V5-122p models have it. I bought a StarTech MDP2HDMI Mini DisplayPort to HDMI Video Adapter Converter and now I can stream from the computer to a LCD TV thru it's HDMI port & get video & sound thru the Mini display port. Don't know why Acer gives you a VGA adapter instead of HDMI(maybe because they say it has HDMI). They also don't sell one either. You can buy the adapter here on Amazon for under $14. Other than that it's great laptop. The touch screen is great. The backlit keyboard is helpfull in low light & only Acer has that. Windows 8 was not that hard to get use to. Go to desk top and you can add Icons so you can use it like the old windows programs. Highly recommend this Acer Aspire. Best price for the features it has.

Reviews.Title: Basic laptop
Reviews.Author: Anon
Reviews.Content: I purchased two of these laptops for my kids. I got a really low price of $373 for each. For the price I paid, this is a decent computer. Both of the laptops I received have had software issues, mainly with the audio and touch screen. I believe that they both had a bad install at the manufacturer. After resetting and reinstalling everything, I haven't had a problem... yet.

Reviews.Title: I've been underwhelmed; it seems underpowered
Reviews.Author: James Korsmo "developing theology"
Reviews.Content: I was excited to get this Windows 8 touchscreen laptop. I have a Windows 8 phone, which I'm very happy with, and I was excited to have similar functionality in a PC. Is laptop is a nice compact size, is quite lightweight, and seems decently built. The bottom plastic seems a bit cheap, but the overall package is pretty nice. It has one USB 3.0 plug and one USB 2.0 plug along with an SD card reader and one mini-HDMI port (no DVD-ROM; not unexpected on a compact machine). It has 1.0 GHz Dual-Core AMD processor and 6 BG of DDR3 Memory.This brings me to my first, and primary issue, with this machine. It seems like it should be up to basic tasks, but I have been quite unhappy with its speed in conducting even simple processes; it almost seems as if the processor is outmatched by the operating system, as things tend to be slow in opening and prone to failing. It was horrific to start with, but a system refresh helped some, but not enough. I had to do a complete system reset (thankfully the software to do so is included) on this machine, which I had had for only two weeks! That helped a bit more, but it's still pretty underwhelming. Even web browsing is slow and awkward (it takes twenty seconds sometimes for internet explorer to get itself open and onto my mail home page), even over a high-speed connection (it doesn't have an ethernet port, so I don't know if the wi-fi modem is partly to blame; I know the connection itself is plenty fast on all of my other devices and computers). It takes between twenty and forty (!) seconds to open iTunes. That's just plain unacceptable. Playing music using iTunes over the Bluetooth connection to my speakers is touchy and prone to skipping and hitching. If everything on the machine is close except iTunes, it usually plays relatively well, but if anything else is happening at all, it starts skipping and pausing and even breaks down sometimes (certainly no web browsing or working while listening to music). And that's just a simple task of playing music over Bluetooth. I have had to resort to plugging it in with a physical cord. I haven't run any more involved programs, but I don't hold out a lot of hope for something like PhotoShop. I was primarily hoping to use this PC for web browsing and playing music. And it's only so so at even those basic tasks.A few other observations. I'm rather unhappy with the track pad, which isn't particularly responsive (I found clicking and dragging to be particularly difficult). The screen quality seems quite good. The touch and multi-touch are relatively responsive, and the picture is bright and clear. The built-in speakers are more or less what you would expect for a compact laptop: not too good. The battery life seems very short, especially with media applications like music or video. And if I leave it hibernating for more than a day, it's dead, so it even bleeds power at a pretty good clip when not running.Overall, this is okay as a cheap laptop, but I found it to be underpowered. I felt like I stepped back a decade or two (!), having to wait for programs to open and websites to load. These most-basic tasks should be effortless, but on my machine, at least, they aren't. Maybe I've got a lemon, as others seem to be very satisfied with performance. I will continue to try resolve the serious functionality issues, and if I make any progress, I will definitely update, but I wanted to register this "minority report," as it describes my experience. I am frustrated with this thing almost all the time.

Reviews.Title: 3 weeks after purchasing it crashed.
Reviews.Author: sarah pickell
Reviews.Content: I was excited to get this laptop because my 8 year old laptop finally broke. The laptop itself was very nice. I hate windows 8. 3 weeks after having this laptop it froze from an update. Couldn't turn it off so I had to press the reset button. Turned it back on and it completely wiped out the computer. I had to buy a windows 8 recovery disc. Acer tech support sucks as well. They didn't even sound surprised that it stopped functioning. They just told me what I already knew to reinstall Windows 8. I'm still waiting for my windows 8 disc but hopefully it works. Not happy that my new laptop is already having issues!

Reviews.Title: Problems and more Problems
Reviews.Author: GLM
Reviews.Content: I purchased this Acer V5 Windows 8 Laptop from Amazon and it was delivered on 11 Sept 2013.After completing the (seemingly) 8,000 Windows updates, the laptop had to be restored twice before it would run without some difficulty for more than 30 minutes.  Then, for a few days, it ran OK but was extremely hot.Then, yesterday and this morning, it started displaying error messages and indicating that the system would shut down and restart itself. Oh joy!  That happened 3 consecutive times.After that, I decided to do the most complete restore option and I'm waiting for that procedure to complete now. Jeeeeeeeeeeeze!!!!If this Acer V5 Laptop doesn't operate as it should after the complete restore, then it will be going back to Amazon on Wednesday, most likely.I  know that with "electronics" you generally get what you pay for. But since this is 2013, I thought I would take a chance.Lesson learned - lesson learned!

Reviews.Title: Not good value
Reviews.Author: Sacha V
Reviews.Content: I purchased this to use solely as a word processor. I cleared out all the bloatware and installed MS Word 2013. The 1GHz processor is impossibly slow and couldn't even handle a single document. As soon as I loaded a 50k word document, it crashed. Re-boot, opened Word, opened document, crash. Then the USB stopped working.Sent it back and got a Lenovo. Totally happy with it.

Reviews.Title: worst piece of junk
Reviews.Author: Amazon Customer "rdm0818"
Reviews.Content: worked just OK for a few weeks, then noticed a big slowdown in processing speed....took to Best Buy Geeks and they said the processor shares with video or something like that  and that slows it all down....now I'm past the 30 day to return deadline and I'm stuck with it....DO NOT BUY THIS JUNK !!!!

Reviews.Title: very good
Reviews.Author: Vivek Anand
Reviews.Content: Good machine, amazingly light with all the features one would expect.  The touch screen is an added benefits.  Only possible thing missing is an SSD although the speed was quite acceptable.

Reviews.Title: was slow on explorer but is fast on firefox....great laptop for basics
Reviews.Author: Denise
Reviews.Content: was very slow on internet explorer but i deleted preinstalled games off it and downloaded firefox and it works fast now...thats the key with this laptop...is great for school work or just youtube and netfleck

Reviews.Title: Haaaappy!!
Reviews.Author: Paola Alarcon
Reviews.Content: just great!! I got a previous version like two years ago for school I decided to replace it and this was an excellent choise!!!

Reviews.Title: It's worth it!
Reviews.Author: James  Dediego
Reviews.Content: It's everything I wanted in an entry level laptop. Runs smooth with windows 8.1, touch screen is so awesome, and has enough speed to game online.

Reviews.Title: I love it!
Reviews.Author: Holly McCarthy
Reviews.Content: This is a great computer. I haven't had a single issue with it. It is fast and it can handle streaming Netflix. I am typing my review on this computer. Haha

Reviews.Title: Incredible Buy with AWESOME features
Reviews.Author: Matthew T. Oakey
Reviews.Content: BACKLIT Keyboard !OVER 4 hours battery runtime !GIGABIT wired and 802.11N !BLUETOOTH !HDMI !TOUCHSCREEN !!!!!Need I say more...

Reviews.Title: OK laptop, but way overpriced
Reviews.Author: Christian De Freitas
Reviews.Content: For those who are not familiar with amd processors, this a6-1450 is benched way under intel celerons, where Celerons get a passmark score of give or take 2000, this CPU gets a score of 1600.for the same price i would go to a core i3 that gets a score of over 3000there's this one http://amzn.to/1iwMEoV with CPU have a score of 2300 (way much cheaper, nicer design)this other one http://amzn.to/1jXG3n0 with CPU score of 3200 (Very nice laptop, i have this model)I know benchmarks is not everything but i have to warn you, this is slower than the intel celeron.Reference numbers from cpu benchmark .net

Reviews.Title: Good value. Beware the trackpad issues.
Reviews.Author: Marcela Mendez
Reviews.Content: I bought this Acer computer in October last year. I have to say it's a great value, it is fast enough for normal everyday computing needs (browsing, emailing), and it's a good looking thing, very stylish design.The shortcoming though, is its trackpad. As many more reviews say, it's unresponsive at times, not sensitive enough and sometimes inaccurate. I had to cope with it for a couple of months (wasn't a very big deal because the touchscreen helps a lot) before I decided to return it to Amazon. As always, Amazon gave me the best possible customer service and a refund was issued to my account the very next day.I wouldn't say this is a reason to underestimate Acer as a brand, they make some really nice computers and airways seem to aim for the lowest possible price point. Most of them are great value for the money. I had two Acer laptops before this one, and the one I just bought (with the money from the refund) is an Acer.Bottom line: this is a great value for the money and if it wasn't for the malfunctioning trackpad I would definitely still be using it, and I would have rated it 4 or even 5 stars.

Reviews.Title: Acer is the BEST!!
Reviews.Author: dERRICK l hEAD
Reviews.Content: Excellent!! As usualAcer makes a wonderful product at a great price. Compact, powerful feature rich. with Windows 8.0 USB 3.0 and HDMI outputs the only thing this is missing is a DVD-Ron drvve. However, due to it's size that is not possible. Also, the touch screen is GREAT!!

Reviews.Title: Fantastic
Reviews.Author: sassylassie
Reviews.Content: I have already recommended it to several people.  The product came so fast it surprised me. I just love the lightweight and the size.  I had a 15 inch laptop that was way too heavy. This is perfect. I think the Windows 8.1 is the reason I am so happy with the size, because you can make the photo larger. Great product all the way around.

Reviews.Title: Good portable laptop with somewhat limited battery life
Reviews.Author: Margaret Picky
Reviews.Content: The 11.6 in. Acer Aspire V5-122P-0863 Touchscreen Laptop is quite similar to a Samsung Chromebook or MacBook Air in size, weight, and appearance except for the beautiful glossy touchscreen and the black undercarriage. The physical build is sturdy and attractive. The backlit keyboard and clickable touchpad function well and the touchscreen is very responsive. The processor is more than adequate.Unfortunately and surprisingly, battery life is disappointing for such an extremely portable package, around four hours depending on what it's being used for. Dimming the screen helps though cycling the battery doesn't. Acer needs to do something about the battery life.I don't like the position of the power button on the outside edge and there are only two USB ports. In addition, to connect it to a monitor, a proprietary adapter cable available only from Acer is recommended--but they don't seem to be selling it yet. There is no ethernet socket: either use the excellent WiFi or get a USB-to-ethernet adapter. The AC adapter and plug are combined, which is nice, and the plug itself can be interchanged for international use, but it can hog three sockets on a power strip. It may be possible to get another power cable--but that shouldn't be necessary.So overall, this is definitely a nice if imperfect piece of hardware with great quality in feel and function in all major aspects other than than battery life. However, it comes with Windows 8 installed, and that is where problems arise.My rating is for the hardware only and does not take into account the software. However, the operating system is an important part of the computing experience so it does require some discussion.Over 10% of the 484 GB hard drive is filled with the OS and pre-installed software. Initially, it took over eight hours to remove junk software and download and install all the Windows 8 software updates with occasional problems requiring trouble-shooting and lots of mandatory restarts. The Windows software was recent, installed about two months before I updated it.It's just as difficult in use: Windows 8 seems to have a split personality between tiles and desktop and is very unintuitive in organization and flow. It is difficult to switch between programs or go back to the desktop and it can takes a lot of swiping and clicking to find something. Worse, sometimes I just can't ever make it do what I want it to do. For instance, when playing music through an online service, the music stops when the window is minimized to switch to another program so I can't read and listen to music at the same time.In the end, I would recommend this little Acer Aspire computer--but only for someone who knows from experience that they want to use Windows 8 over another OS and for whom four hours of battery life is sufficient. I have a Mac mini and a Samsung Chromebook and have not found any reason to prefer the Acer Aspire for any particular use, primarily because of the operating system, although I like the backlit keyboard and the beautiful touchscreen very much.Again, my rating is for the hardware only and does not take into account the software.

Reviews.Title: A Good (Not Great) Touchscreen Laptop
Reviews.Author: Roger N. Overton
Reviews.Content: I'm a graduate student and I run a small online business on the side. So my primary uses for the laptop are school, email, and various office programs. I'm not a gamer, so I haven't tested the laptop other than to play Cut the Rope which was pre-installed (and excellent!).As a student, one of my primary concerns with a laptop is battery life. This is one of the few areas where the Acer is weak or mediocre. Fully charged it seems to have a little more than 3 hours of juice. These days that's surprisingly short. I wonder if the backlit keyboard drains it a bit- I'm not sure.Another concern of mine is weight and size. When I'm carrying textbooks with me I don't want to unnecessarily add more weight. This Acer excels here. It's light, small, and easy to handle. The power adapter is a bit bulky at the plug, but still smaller than any other laptop power adapter I've ever used, so that's an improvement.It's worth noting that this does NOT have a CD-ROM drive. That's becoming standard for laptops this size and tablets, but it may be surprising for people switching over from larger devices. Everything is going toward cloud storage and programing, and this laptop comes with Acer Cloud software. However, like everything else with this machine, very little instruction is offered on how to set it up, how to use it, and what to use it for. People new to this technology will be fairly confused. On that note, people new to Windows 8 will be incredibly confused. I'm still adjusting. However, the faults of Windows 8 are not Acer's fault.The best feature of the laptop, apart from its size and weight, is the touchscreen. I wasn't sure if I would like it- it turns out I love it. It makes navigating web and app content significantly better on a laptop. It's very responsive with pinpoint sensitivity. Much like when I transitioned from a full QWERTY keyboard phone to a touchscreen smartphone, I now can't imagine going back to pre-touchscreen days.The speakers are as good as I'd expect for a laptop like this, with decent sound for being underneath. However, the mute button is not with the other volume control buttons, which just seems odd. I don't use webcams often (hardly ever), but I played with this one for the review. I was surprised at its low quality, though I'm not sure how it compares to others. One last annoyance is that the touchpad is noisy and clunky. Thankfully, you can adjust the sensitivity, which was way too high when I began using it.In summary-Pros:-Touchscreen-Size & Weight-Decent sound and video qualityCons:-Touchpad-Battery life-Lack of instructionIn a nutshell: If you're a student like me, and you refuse to buy Mac products, this is a product to consider. You definitely compare this to other devices first, but there's a good chance this will meet your needs at its reasonable price point.

Reviews.Title: Bought this to replace a ChromeBook  BIG MISTAKE
Reviews.Author: daniel
Reviews.Content: I travel a lot and needed a small laptop to do basic work.  Word processing, web surfing, email and Skype.  I didn't do my research and ordered a ChromeBook C7 which although fantastic on internet speed, does not run Skype.  Sure Google offers similar programs as SKYPE but none and I mean none have worked for me while overseas.  Even after working with the NINJA team to solve the issue.SO I had this little Acer Aspire V5  send out as it is Windows based, which will run Skype and I love windows to be honest.  Took three weeks to get to me as I'm overseas and when I got it I was ecstatic.  Finally I thought my problems are solved, but no.  From the initial boot up I had issue after issue.  VERY slow  to do ANYTHING.  It is painfully slow to turn on, open explorer, Skype, etc.  I cannot stand Windows 8 at all, not user friendly at all.  The touch screen is absolute nonsense and I would never purchase this computer again.It is beyond slow for absolutely everything I try and do.  It often crashes while I try to open Skype, internet and quite a bit of the time the screen flickers on and off.  Booting it up needs to be done a couple times just to actually get it to fully fire up.Overall I have to say I'm very disappointed with everything about this computer except the size and appearance.  I have a Toshiba satellite from eight years ago that runs faster with less trouble than this computer.  If you ask me that's criminal, please spend your money on something better and save some hassle with this junk computer.  I wish I had ordered a MAC or something better from someone else.Hope this helps someone, Cheers

Reviews.Title: It has Windows 8  Otherwise a great laptop
Reviews.Author: movieofficiando "MO"
Reviews.Content: HATE windows 8, but the hardware seems fine.  A little slow, but compensated for by the size about the size of a piece of paper and about as thick as a pile of 80 pages??.  Fits in my purse and is light weight as well as well.Maybe I mentioned, I HATE windows 8.  It comes with a free 8.1 update, but don't let anyone kid you.  8.1 is a pain too.  I figure we'll all be stuck with 8 or something similar sooner or later so I bit the bullet.  Ugh!

Reviews.Title: great portable notebook
Reviews.Author: M. Fisher
Reviews.Content: Again another black Firday purchase I believe 250. without looking it up.  I have an Ipad i crusie around on too but sometimes like a real keyboard and mouse when i am looking up stuff and multitasking ie travel airlines changing datess etc.. love the back lit keyboard and this was my first experience with windows 8.  and an cheap way to play with it and learn it.  Has the touch screen which i use some but not near as much as the standard keyboard.  My relaxing time is a typical Lazy boy recliner and this fits great.I have't had the need but may miss an Hdmi out to stream it to a tv the on board speakers are plenty and deeper sounding that i thought.  As in most smaller unit no optical drive.  So if dvd or Cd is a big thing to you you will miss it.  I would leave it at home for travel as my Ipad travels easier and better battery life.  I have had many Acer products over the years and have always been pleased.  A little Christmas gift to my self!!

Reviews.Title: Very slow computer
Reviews.Author: A. Martin "tony_fourbu"
Reviews.Content: The computer looks sharp and very portable. However it is extremely slow. I think the slow CPU needs a SSD RAM, not a mechanical hard drive. The slowness, even when browsing, was unbearable - much slower than our 7-year old laptop the Acer was replacing. We shipped it back and ordered a Chromebook, for half the price, and don't regret this decision at all. Either get a Chromebook or a faster ultrabook or a MacAir, but not this one.

Reviews.Title: So far, so good
Reviews.Author: Sean L.
Reviews.Content: With the caveat that I've only been using the computer for three days, so far I'm pleasantly surprised. The keyboard feels solid, and the backlight is a fantastic (and often times, overlooked) feature. The one thing I will say is that you would be wise to upgrade to 6 GB of RAM to prevent any lag. I wanted to give it a chance with the 4 GB it came with, but I'll be swapping out one of those 2 GB spots for a 4 GB sometime this week. I haven't unplugged to test the battery life, but I'm assuming 3 hours is about where it will fall. I figured it would be a bit gimmicky, but the touchscreen is actually really useful. I'm not as critical of Windows 8 as some others, and I actually find it kind of fun once you learn your way around, but this is a great little laptop for the price. I'll update with a more comprehensive review in a month or two, but right now I'm happy with the purchase.

Reviews.Title: Don't waste your money on this
Reviews.Author: maxthor66
Reviews.Content: This computer is one of the worst computers I have ever seen. First off, I payed $600 for it and in the first few days I had to pay $150 to get viruses removed. I then payed $100 for a solid antivirus and this computer still has the most insane glitches. It can't even stay connected to the internet for more than 30 minutes and I also payed $100 for Microsoft Office. I ended paying the price of a MacBook Air for a computer that has a track pad that can barely function, gets 2 hours of battery life, and is slow as a snail. Get a MacBook or a better Windows 8 PC. Don't waste your money on this.

Reviews.Title: Got this for my son
Reviews.Author: Jack Menough
Reviews.Content: My son loves this, great deal and a great price!! Everything you should expect from a Acer 11.6-Inch computer, better than you store brand!!

Reviews.Title: Capable performer in most respects, but dismal battery life is a dealbreaker
Reviews.Author: The Bee Bee "BB"
Reviews.Content: Rather than go through the blah, blah, blah of listing the pros and cons, I'm going to cut to the chase: In spite of some noteworthy features, the inexplicably poor battery life on the new Acer Aspire V5-122P-0863 11.6-Inch Touchscreen Laptop is reason enough to take it off your shopping list.I really, really wanted to love this laptop. It's got many (but not all) of the bells and whistles a buyer is looking for this year - Windows 8, a terrific touchscreen display (albeit at a rather outdated 1366 x 768 pixel resolution), plenty of RAM and hard drive space to satisfy most users - but what good does any of it do you when you run out of power two hours and change into your flight, or midway through your night class?This kind of battery performance is unacceptable these days, and when the competition's offerings (particularly tablets) offer 7-12 hours of juice on a charge--well, all I can ask is what is Acer thinking? The company has produced so many truly exceptional computers during the past few years (check out the incredible Acer S7 ultrabooks) that when they toss off a dud like this, it sticks out like a sore thumb.

Reviews.Title: DO NOT BUY IF YOU PLAN TO USE WITH VIRTUALIZATION!
Reviews.Author: nixcomputer
Reviews.Content: I just bought my Acer Aspire V5-122P planning to use it as a development machine (paid quite a bit for it) and I was pretty dissapointed to find that the AMD virtualization extension, which is supported by the CPU, was disabled. Also noticed that for BIOS v2.08 there is no option for virtulization to enable/disable it in BIOS. On the AMD website the A6-1450 has AMD-V as a supported feature. Yet, when I try to run my virutal machines (Oracle VirtualBox or even VMWare Player) it says that the host does not support Virtulization AMD-V.

Reviews.Title: A Wonderful Little Laptop
Reviews.Author: Alexander Lucard
Reviews.Content: I wasn't sure I was going to fall in love with this little laptop, to be honest. After experiencing the performance (and size limitations) of my husband's Acer netbook, I had some reservations going in.  The screen and keyboard were much smaller than what I was used to; it doesn't even have a numeric keypad (I can't even tell you why that's important to me - it's not like I use it that much at home!). It also doesn't have a CD drive. I was a little put off by the thought that it would be slow or buggy.  But really, it's not like I play a lot of graphics heavy games (Farmville does NOT count), stream a lot of movies/video, nor run a lot of complicated programs. I rarely listen to music on the PC since I bought an iPhone, and 90% of the software I have on disc is out of date anyway (why am I keeping these discs?).  I basically use my home laptop for surfing the Net and writing papers (with maybe the occasional bit of day job work thrown in for good measure).So after realizing those things, this little guy started sounding better and better.  It's a touchscreen!  It's Windows 8! It has a six gig hard drive! It's light and small and adorable!The main thing I noticed (and loved) right out of the box was how sturdy it is.  My last laptop was made of a thinner plastic and was kind of flimsy.  Not only could my cat not nap on the closed laptop without causing serious damage to the screen, the "h" key popped partway off after maybe a month.  Of course, cats probably shouldn't nap on laptops, but I believe this little Aspire could handle it if one of them decided to.  Also, the (backlit!) keyboard looks to be made of stronger stuff. If there's any size difference at all, I can't tell it.  I do notice the lack of a numeric keyboard, but most people wouldn't.Windows 8 takes some getting used to.  This is in no way a reflection on the machine itself - it can't help the OS that was installed on it. But it does seem that most of things I don't care for are associated with Windows 8.  I'm used to the "Desktop" being the first thing I see when I log on to my computer.  With Windows 8, the Start Screen - which replaced the Start Menu we're all used to using - pops up first instead, and you can access your Desktop from that.  It's not intuitive in the least (at least for me).  It took me two days to figure out how to turn the power off without cheating and resorting to ctrl + alt + delete!I don't understand the need for "apps" on my laptop. Maybe I'm missing the point, but I understood apps to be lighter versions of software for use on smartphones and tablets - I expect my computer to be able to run full "applications" or "programs," first of all.  And second, I use my laptop in an entirely different way than I use my smartphone or tablet.  It just seems completely unnecessary to have a Netflix app on my start menu when I can stream video from the Netflix site easily from my web browser and enjoy full access to search features and the ability to edit my queues. I uninstalled and unpinned a lot of these silly things, because all they were doing was cluttering up my Start Screen.I did keep the mail app for a few weeks, because it looked cool.  That's about all it had going for it, actually.  I wasn't able to add all of my accounts to it (though my gmail and Outlook accounts were effortless).  But my main issue was how it handled attachments - it didn't.  So back to Office Outlook I went. Unfortunately, if you delete the Mail app, you also delete the Messenger and Contacts apps...Contacts I don't need, but I would like to try the Messenger app at some point.I didn't like that Windows 8 prompted me to create a Microsoft Account during set up.  It then used this ID and password to log me into the machine.  I was able to go in and change this later, of course, but it still doesn't sit well with me that I wasn't given the option during set up.The laptop came with a free trial of the new Office 360.  I don't agree with how they've handled the licensing for this product, so I installed my good old Office 2010 instead,  with no problems.Is it less powerful than my old computer?  I honestly don't see any difference. If it's any slower, or if there have been any lags, they haven't been enough to grab my attention so far. As for battery life, I get about the same amount of time as with my last HP laptop.  The cord is much smaller, thinner, and lighter, too, which is good when you have a cord-loving rabbit in the house.The only real problem I have experienced is with Chrome.  Chrome is my default browser for a number of reasons, the least of which being the ability to sync between devices.  That's not something I'm willing to give up.  However, I've noticed that half the time it doesn't start up properly.  And because of the way it runs in Windows 8 (it takes up the entire screen; there is no "red x" to close out of it, and your task tray does not appear at all) closing it out isn't quick and simple anymore.  You also can't resize the screen and have Chrome run side-by-side with other programs (a trick I was bad to employ with data entry tasks).  I can't say if this is a problem with the computer or with Windows 8.  I have had at least one person tell me that Chrome is the only browser he can get to run in 8 with any stability...and another to tell me she couldn't get Chrome to work at all!The laptop is amazingly light and easy to handle.  I can see myself traveling with it without any problems, and I have always had problems lugging a laptop in the past.  I've never really been the kind of person who sat the laptop on my lap, actually, but I find myself doing so with this machine.

Reviews.Title: Cannot upgrade to windows 8.1
Reviews.Author: Mark in Boulder
Reviews.Content: The ACER support system is terrible.Laptop freezes up often.Seems slow.Feels heavy for its size.Battery life is lower than specs.

Reviews.Title: CD/DVD-ROM
Reviews.Author: Yousuf "Jonny"
Reviews.Content: Well, I love the product.I want to buy for my MBA. Seems a perfect choice, but I wonder if the computer has a CD/DVD-ROM???Best regards,Yousuf

Reviews.Title: UNHAPPY ACER CUSTOMER!! CHEAP, SLOW, AND NONPRODUCTIVE
Reviews.Author: Debbie Loudermelt
Reviews.Content: Freezes most of the time and is SUPER slow other times. Not a reliable laptop at all. I purchased for work and rely on my laptop for work. Big mistake buying this one! It's a budget laptop for surfing online only.

Reviews.Title: acer aspire v5
Reviews.Author: IOAN P.
Reviews.Content: good but not fantastic,the hard is slow,win 8 too complicated,i d'ont like,i change with windos 7,

Reviews.Title: Amazingly Fast for a NetBook form factor.
Reviews.Author: G. Grant "BigG"
Reviews.Content: This is a great little computer for a great price ($278) delivered from Amazon.  It has windows 8 installed from the factory. But if you buy it, upgrade it to Windows 8.1 before you install other software.  Initially I installed Rosetta Stone (before the Win8.1 update) and it lost it's registraton through the update process. It seems like it takes forever to update (via windows update) 73 updates.  But when It completes the computer runs great. I use PowerDVD 13 Ultra to play videos and found that this little computer can play BluRay videos without 'jerkiness'.  It is a FOUR real CORE AMD processors and plays video smoothly. It has one USB3.0 port and one USB2 port and what appears to be a mini-Display Port.  The Netbook comes with a VGA dongle to use an external VGA monitor.The computer's body very light and the screen in very readable.

Reviews.Title: Don't bother.  Look elsewhere.
Reviews.Author: Michael Clark
Reviews.Content: Way too much money for this product.  This basically is a very slow typewriter.  Was very disappointed as this computer could not even meet a high schooler's needs.

Reviews.Title: It looks great, but isn't without a few snags...
Reviews.Author: Andrew Ellington
Reviews.Content: It's lightweight and stylish, which go a long way for portable computers.  For someone looking for a notebook that is easy to travel with and is a very convenient use, this is one they should look into.  Sadly, style cannot cover over every blemish, and some of the laptops faults are issues one would need to really think out.For me, the biggest drawback to the computer is the battery usage.  The charge does NOT last very long.  Even when the computer is not in usage, the battery drains rather quickly.  In fact, after a full charge I put the computer up and got busy and didn't get to touch it for a few days.  When I turned it on it was completely dead and I had to recharge it again.  When using the computer it drains even faster, obviously.  Another issue I had here was the loading time.  The computer is very slow.  In this fast paced society, that is an issue and one that anyone using this for business may want to factor in.  I personally got this to use for work, but thankfully my job doesn't force me to be so quick all the time, thus the annoying wait time not being a giant issue for me.  I can live with it, even if I don't want to.That being said, the computer itself is pretty easy to use once you get the hang of it.  There is a lot to offer here, and the many features are ones that I'm sure any tech savvy person is going to salivate over.  Some of it I haven't had the time to get to know better, and some of it I'm still trying to understand n concept, but there is enough to play with here to make the computer a fun experience.

Reviews.Title: Machine too slow with horrid support from Acer
Reviews.Author: Fiji Sunrise
Reviews.Content: I chose this machine for features for the price.  Nice IPS screen, backlit KB, decent build.  Even with the A6 AMD this thing is horribly slow.  Its torture to use it. It can't even open web pages worth a crap.  The processor just is clocked too slow at 1 ghz and maybe turbos up just a tad over but believe me, the APU is a major bottleneck for performance and you can't fix that.  SSD may help a bit but its not worth the price to upgrade to SSD with little gain in performance.  It shortly had a display failure and I sent it to ACER for replacement.  Note, ACER makes the customer pay for shipping.  Even if you pay 1700 dollars for their S7 and it DOA brand new, you pay for shipping.  After I got it back, the display worked, but the extended battery I bought will not charge now.  So obviously, they damaged the main board when replacing my display.  But they would not fix it.  They said call Acer and get new battery.  Acer accessories says they don't have the battery anymore and don't know if and when they will get them.  Even though I know the battery is still good.  I just needed another battery to prove to repair center that its not the battery but the device itself that won't charge the battery.  Anyway, don't listen to other reviews saying the A6 is good enough.  This machine is slow, I mean really slow.  Save yourself a ton of grief and pay a little more and get something with an Intel ulv or mobile processor.  This is one of AMD's worse APU's. Even my old HP DM1 with the AMD E-350 performed much better then the A6.  Again, this is a 1 ghz processor.  That's all you need to know.  And Acer support is one of the worst.  Its not worth it.

Reviews.Author: S. Sowerbutts "book junkie"
Reviews.Content: I bought this for my son for school. He loves it. He can connect to his xbox so I'm pretty sure his grades are shot!! I guess I should give this a lower rating.

Reviews.Title: acer aspire V5-122P0857 11.6 inch touchscreen lapton
Reviews.Author: marianella bolivar
Reviews.Content: It's also a good lapto to comply with the requirement thats requested, I am very pleased to have thes computer. I recommend it to everyone who looking for a lapto

Reviews.Title: A $400 MISTAKE!
Reviews.Author: Nathan King
Reviews.Content: TOO SLOW! Bought it for my son, he hated it! Gave to my wife she hated it! Both say it's too slow. It takes about 2 mins to start up. I waited too long so I can't return it. I'm guessing the processors not powerful enough to run the new Windows. I'm an Apple guy so not up to speed on Windows. Going to take it to someone to see if they can remove all the BS so maybe it will run faster.

Reviews.Title: Awful
Reviews.Author: Danny Marchese
Reviews.Content: Just as cheap, unreliable, and minimally functional as every other Acer product. If you're still buying from the Kia of laptop manufacturers, then you deserve what you get.

Reviews.Title: By far, the worst laptop I've ever owned
Reviews.Author: Greg D. Matthews
Reviews.Content: The Acer Aspire V5 is the worst laptop I've ever owned. I was hoping for a mobile device for the bus to replace my aging 1st generation tablet. A few issues: 1) Randomly opens some functionality associated with the touch screen that prevents you from typing. 2) Generally can handle only one browser open at a time and maybe 4 tabs. 3) The computer is slow - Windows 3 slow. 4) Windows 8 appears to be something just thrown together to respond to the touch screen market. I don't find it practical and it does not integrate into windows basic functionality. No thoughts of user centered design. 5) Touch pad commonly glitchy. 6) Battery life not good.This is not a Apple or Android replacement.

Reviews.Title: It sucks
Reviews.Author: drillit2
Reviews.Content: This is the worst computer i have owned. If you want to multi task this is not the computer to get. It is very slow, and windows 8 just sucks. It does not have an hdmi port as stated. Overall its not worth the money.

Reviews.Title: no hdmi PORT
Reviews.Author: Frederick Hamilton
Reviews.Content: 1. computer left at front door at 9pm at night . no bell rung, no signature requested or given, yet this is what it states on the tracking.Little did I know the abilities of my front door, to be able to read and write ???Ship Carrier: oNTRACTracking Number:  C11229009710485Status: DeliveredSigned for by: front door2.  Where is the HDMI PORT ?????Product DescriptionAcer V5-122P-0637 Touch Screen Notebook comes with these high level specs: AMD A-Series Quad-Core Processor A6-1450, Windows 8, 11.6" HD Widescreen CineCrystal LED-backlit Display, Multi-touch screen, supporting 10 finger touch, AMD A70M Fusion chipset, AMD Radeon HD 8250 graphics with 512MB of memory, 6144MB DDR3 Memory, 500GB SATA Hard Drive (5400RPM), Secure Digital (SD) card reader, 802.11b/g/n Wi-Fi CERTIFIED, Bluetooth 4.0+HS, Built-In HD Webcam, 1 - USB 3.0 Port, 1 - USB 2.0 Port, 1 - HDMI Port, 1 - Acer Converter Port (with Dongle - VGA Port), 3-cell Li-ion Battery (2640 mAh), Up to 3.5-hours Battery Life, 3.04 lbs. - 1.38 kg (system unit only)

Reviews.Title: This laptop is made to screw you up and your business.
Reviews.Author: Ivan C.
Reviews.Content: This Product is absolutely horrible. It doesn't perform it's main function - work. Everyday I use it it automatically shots off in the middle of my work without any option to save your work or opened documents. it's called blue screen of death. Google it. This laptop is made to screw you up and your business.
